questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the clinic by his mother. She reports that the child has been irritable, lethargic, and refusing to eat for the past few weeks and had bilateral lower extremity swelling with a distended abdomen. Based on the clinical presentation, which dermatological manifestation is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)Flaky paint dermatosis​​​​​​​
Explanation:

The given clinical picture suggests the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor, a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by oedema resulting from a deficiency of dietary protein despite sufficient caloric intake.

  • This condition may present with peripheral pitting oedema, muscle atrophy, abdominal distension (hepatomegaly), moon facies, hair and skin changes, anorexia, apathy, and growth retardation.
  • The skin manifestations are distinctive and often described as resembling "cracked skin," "peeling paint," "enamel paint," "flaky paint," or "crazy paving" due to the characteristic scaling and irregular fissures observed during examination.Over time, more defined plaques may develop, particularly in areas prone to friction such as skin folds.
  • The hair frequently takes on a dull, reddish-brown hue that may alternate with more normal colouring, referred to as the "flag sign."

  • Inflammatory changes of the mucous membranes, such as xerophthalmia, cheilitis, stomatitis, and vulvovaginitis, may develop alongside other concurrent deficiencies in vitamins and mineral micronutrients.
  • Treatment focuses on slowly restoring nutrients to prevent refeeding syndrome and related electrolyte imbalances and micronutrient deficiencies.

Option B) Phrynoderma, derived from "toad skin," is a dermatological manifestation linked to vitamin A deficiency, although it can also occur in conjunction with other nutritional deficiencies.

Option C: Corkscrew hair represents fractured and coiled hairs due to disruption in the formation of keratin cross-links through disulfide bonds. It is commonly seen in deficiencies of vitamins C.


Option D: Casal’s necklace is V-shaped eczematous, hyperkeratotic lesions on the anterior aspect of the neck, manifesting as a part of dermatitis in pellagra due to Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency.

Other sites of these eczematous lesions include the dorsum of the hand and face.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented to the dermatological OPD with complaints of painful cracks at the corners of her mouth. On examination, the doctor noticed a smooth magenta-coloured tongue. Which of the following supplements needs to be prescribed to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Riboflavin
Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation of painful cracks at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis) and a smooth magenta-coloured tongue, the most likely deficiency is of Riboflavin (Vitamin B2).

  • Vitamin B2 is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin.
  • The recommended daily intake of riboflavin is 0.3–1.6 mg, depending on age and gender.
  • A deficiency in riboflavin can arise due to reduced dietary consumption, impaired absorption, or exposure to phototherapy.
  • Clinical presentations include angular stomatitis, cheilitis, glossitis, and Seborrhoeic dermatitis-like eruption.
  • The ocular manifestation of riboflavin deficiency is corneal vascularization, which presents as itching and burning in the eyes and increased sensitivity to light.
  • Treatment is with riboflavin supplementation of 1–2 mg/day in infants and children and 10–20 mg/day in adults.

 

Option A) Thiamine:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency primarily leads to a condition known as Beriberi, which is of two types:

  • Wet beriberi has predominant cardiovascular involvement, including cardiomegaly and congestive heart failure.
  • Dry beriberi causes neurological manifestations including peripheral neuropathy and Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

It can result in the development of skin lesions, including patches of redness, scaling, or hyperpigmentation.

Option B) Methylcobalamin:

Vitamin B12 (Methylcobalamin) deficiency presents with haematological manifestations, including megaloblastic anaemia, and dermatological manifestations such as pallor, jaundice, hyperpigmentation, and angular cheilitis.

Although B12 deficiency also causes angular cheilitis, riboflavin deficiency most commonly and primarily affects mucous membranes, which can result in the development of angular cheilitis.

Option D)Folate

Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency also presents with megaloblastic anaemia.

While angular stomatitis and cheilitis are also seen in folate deficiency, the smooth magenta-coloured tongue is commonly associated with riboflavin deficiency.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of poor growth, intermittent episodes of confusion, and a skin rash after sun exposure. On examination, a pellagrous dermatitis rash is noted over the face, sparing eyelids, and the upper surface of the orbit, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Hartnup disease
Explanation:

The above clinical presentation points towards the diagnosis of Hartnup disease, a rare autosomal recessive condition, which is marked by a faulty transport system for neutral amino acids, leading to inadequate absorption of tryptophan and subsequent niacin deficiency.

  • Mutations in the SLC6A19 gene, which encodes a neutral amino acid transporter found in the intestine and kidneys, responsible for this condition.
  • Clinical manifestations include cerebellar ataxia, psychiatric manifestations, aminoaciduria, and pellagra.
  • Niacin deficiency leads to dermatitis on sun-exposed parts of the body.
  • Management includes intake of a high-protein diet and nicotinamide supplementation.
  • Other common causes of niacin deficiency are inadequate dietary intake, carcinoid syndrome, excess maize consumption, and treatment with isoniazid.
  • The tetrad associated with Niacin defieceincy: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia and Death.

Option A) Kwashiorkor:

  • Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition due to a disproportionate intake of carbohydrates (energy or calories) in excess of other macronutrients, specifically proteins.
  • Characteristic features include oedema, muscle atrophy, abdominal distension (hepatomegaly), growth retardation, flaky paint dermatosis, and flag sign.

Option B) Phenylketonuria

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism caused by mutations in the gene encoding phenylalanine hydroxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • It presents with delayed developmental milestones, microcephaly, hypopigmentation, hyperactivity/behaviour problems, seizures, and a musty odour to skin and urine.

Option D) Maple syrup urine disease

  • Maple syrup urine disease is a rare inborn metabolic disorder characterized by diminished activity of the branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • Its classic presentation in the neonatal period includes failure to thrive, delayed developmental milestones, feeding difficulties, and the presence of a maple syrup odor in the urine.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with irritability, diarrhoea, and a rash characterized by vesicles, pustules, and crusting around the mouth and anus. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Zinc deficiency

The infant in this clinical vignette with diarrhoea and peri-oral and peri-genital rashes is probably suffering from Acrodermatitis enteropathica due to zinc deficiency.

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the gene SLC39A4, which encodes the intestinal zinc transporter ZIP4 on enterocytes.
  • The characteristic clinical triad of symptoms comprises diarrhoea, dermatitis, and alopecia.
  • It presents with eczematous rash in periorificial, peri-genital, and acral areas.
  • Onset is usually after 6 months of age (Weaning of the child).
  • Treated with zinc supplements.

Option A) Scurvy

  • Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency, which manifestations involve the skin and oral cavity.
  • Symptoms include bleeding gums, easy bruising, perifollicular haemorrhages (bleeding around hair follicles), corkscrew hair, petechiae, ecchymoses, delayed wound healing, and bone and joint aches.

 

 

 

Option C)Atopic dermatitis

  • Atopic dermatitis is a pruritic inflammatory skin disorder that typically begins in infancy, often before the age of 2.
  • The rash is marked by erythema, itchy papules, or papulovesicles that can progress to become excoriated and thickened (lichenified) and frequently have a flexural distribution.

Option D) Iron deficiency

  • Iron deficiency can result in reduced haemoglobin levels, leading to the pallor of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • Brittle nails and Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) due to the thinning of nail plates can be seen.
  • Iron deficiency may also contribute to hair loss or thinning of the hair.

questions.text: A 45-year-old corporate office worker presents to the clinic after noticing the following skin changes with dull-red papules on his shin, as shown in the image. He reports no itching or pain and no history of trauma. Which of the following initial investigations would be the most relevant for confirming the diagnosis and guiding further management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Fasting blood glucose
Explanation:

The image depicts the presence of asymptomatic, oval, dull-red papules over the shin with no history of trauma suggests that the patient might have Diabetic dermopathy and hence needs to be evaluated for diabetes mellitus with fasting blood glucose levels and HbA1c levels.

  • Diabetes can lead to many skin manifestations such as
    • Acanthosis nigricans,
    • Diabetic dermopathy,
    • Necrobiosis lipoidica,
    • Granuloma annulare,
    • Scleredema diabeticorum,
    • Eruptive xanthomas,
    • Bullous diabeticorum,
    • Pruritus and diabetic bulla.
  • Diabetic dermopathy initially presents as rounded, dull, red papules that progressively evolve over 1-2 weeks into well-circumscribed, atrophic, brown macules, which are distributed bilaterally.
  • The pretibial area is commonly affected, but other bony prominences like forearms or lateral malleoli may also be involved.
  • These patients often exhibit concomitant nephropathy, neuropathy, and retinopathy.
  • Histological examination indicates that the pigmentation results from the dermal deposition of haemosiderin and melanin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old alcoholic patient presented to the OPD with atrophic scars and hyperpigmented lesions on the back of his hands, neck, face, and feet. Urine analysis revealed elevated uroporphyrin levels. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing atrophic scars and hyperpigmented patches along with the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme deficiency indicates that the likely diagnosis is Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).

  • It is the most common porphyria, has a complex inheritance pattern, and is of three types:

Type I (sporadic)

Type II (familial )

Type III

The enzyme deficiency is acquired and restricted to hepatocytes due to the inhibition of a normal UROD enzyme.

The enzyme deficiency is hereditary, present in all tissues, and associated with a UROD gene mutation.

Rare type and is characterized by a hereditary enzyme deficiency localized to the liver.
  • The major risk factors are subclinical genetic hemochromatosis, hepatitis C infection, alcohol, and estrogens.
  • Patients exhibit increased fragility of light-exposed skin, presenting with painful bullae formation, subsequent crusting, and resulting in atrophic scarring, milia, and alterations in pigmentation, either hyper- or hypopigmentation.
  • Histopathology reveals subepidermal bullae with a sparse inflammatory infiltrate and ‘festooning’ of dermal papillae into the bullae.
  • Management includes photoprotection and eliminating the risk factors.
  • Definitive treatment with venesection or low‐dose antimalarials is required in almost all cases.

Option A) Acute intermittent porphyria

  • Acute intermittent porphyria is a rare autosomal dominant disorder marked by hydroxymethylbilane synthase deficiency.
  • Clinical manifestations include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, peripheral neuropathy, and seizures.

Option B) Erythropoietic porphyria

  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) is a hereditary porphyria characterized by chronic photosensitivity and occasional liver disease.
  • It typically arises from deficient ferrochelatase activity, the final enzyme of heme biosynthesis.
  • It manifests most commonly in the first year of life, with excruciating pains on exposure to sunlight.

Option C) Variegate porphyria

  • It is an autosomal dominant inherited deficiency of protoporphyrinogen oxidase.
  • Clinical manifestations include cutaneous blistering lesions (subepidermal vesicles, bullae, and erosions that crust over and heal slowly) of sun-exposed skin, especially the hands and face.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of dark patches on her neck and underarms that developed gradually over the past few months. On examination, velvety hyperpigmentation is seen over the affected areas. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is not correct?

choices.text: Primarily caused by excessive melanin production in the affected areas
It is a cutaneous marker for underlying metabolic abnormalities
Seen in patients with gastrointestinal cancers
Skin tags are commonly associated with this condition

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Primarily caused by excessive melanin production in the affected areas
Explanation:
The presence of velvety hyperpigmentation hints at the condition of Acanthosis nigricans. The pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis; there is no increase in melanocytes or melanin production. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in intertriginous areas.
  • It typically occurs in individuals younger than the age of 40 years and is associated with obesity, hypothyroidism, acromegaly, PCOS, insulin-resistant diabetes, and Cushing and Addison diseases.
  • It manifests as asymptomatic, symmetrical darkening of the skin, particularly in the axillae, groins, sub mammary folds, and neck.
  • Pathogenesis: Increased production of IGF-1 (Insulin-like growth factor 1).
  • Acanthosis nigricans is of two types:
  1. Benign: Mild, localized, and associated with obesity, diabetes mellitus and other metabolic syndromes.
  2. Malignant: Rapid in onset, generalized, and associated with visceral malignancy like Adenocarcinoma of GIT (Option C).
  • The goal of treatment is to treat the underlying disease; Keratolytics, such as topical retinoids and podophyllin can be used.

Option B) It is a cutaneous marker for underlying metabolic abnormalities

This statement is correct as Acanthosis nigricans is commonly seen in associated metabolic conditions like DM, obesity, metabolic syndrome, OCP use, and insulin resistance.

Option D) Skin tags are commonly associated with this condition

Acanthosis nigricans typically begins with asymptomatic darkening of the skin in the neck, axillae, and groin regions. Over time, these patches thicken and may lead to the formation of skin tags in the affected areas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with persistent unilateral nipple crusting and eczematous changes, with occasional bleeding. On examination, the affected nipple appears erythematous and flattened, with nipple retraction noted. There are no palpable breast masses. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Paget's disease
Explanation:

The above clinical vignette suggests that the patient is suffering from Paget’s disease of the nipple.

 

  • A progressive, marginated scaling or crusting of the nipple and areola due to invasion of the epidermis by malignant cells, which usually originate from an intraductal carcinoma of the breast.
  • Unilateral eczematous lesions, with a typical well-demarcated border seen on the nipple.
  • Biopsy shows characteristic Paget cells that are present in the stratum spinosum.
  • Surgery should be carried out for carcinoma of the breast.

Option A) Eczematous dermatitis

Typically bilateral and not associated with nipple retraction or bleeding. Can present with a scaly, itchy rash and typically does not have well-demarcated borders

Option B) Psoriasis

Psoriasis is characterized by well-defined, scaly plaques but usually affects the skin elsewhere on the body and does not typically involve the nipple.
Psoriasis would be characterized by hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and Munro microabscesses, rather than the atypical Paget cells found in Paget’s disease.

Option C) Mondor’s disease

Mondor's disease manifests as thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

A characteristic feature is the presence of a tender, thrombosed subcutaneous cord, often adherent to the skin.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has had recurrent abdominal pain, joint pain, and reddish-purple spots on his legs and buttocks for the past week. The spots don't fade when pressed, and he has swelling in his knees and ankles. He also has mild blood in his stools and had no sick contacts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and lab investigations support the diagnosis of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura.

  • IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein Purpura, primarily affects the small vessels of the joints, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and skin.
  • Cutaneous findings include erythematous, urticarial papules, which may evolve into palpable purpura with haemorrhage within 24 hours.
  • This condition typically involves the extensor aspect of limbs and buttocks but can also involve the trunk, hands, and face.
  • Renal involvement: Gross/microscopic hematuria with proteinuria.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement: Abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Painful arthritis.
  • Less common manifestations include pancreatitis, orchitis, neurological abnormalities, carditis, and pulmonary haemorrhage.
  • Biopsy reveals IgA-containing immune complexes in the walls of small blood vessels.
  • Treatment: In children, the condition is self-limiting whereas in adults, colchicine and steroids can be given.

Option B) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can present with a variety of symptoms, including skin rashes and joint pain.
  • Butterfly Rash (Malar Rash): A characteristic facial rash that appears as a butterfly-shaped erythematous rash across the cheeks and nose bridge. It often has a “slapped cheek” appearance.
  • Discoid Rash: Chronic, disk-shaped lesions that are scaly and often appear on sun-exposed areas. These rashes can lead to scarring and are distinct from the malar rash.

Option C) Rheumatic fever

  • Rheumatic fever is associated with a history of streptococcal throat infection and primarily affects the heart, joints, and skin (e.g., erythema marginatum).
  • Erythema Marginatum: This is a key dermatological feature of rheumatic fever, characterized by erythematous, ring-shaped lesions with a pale center and raised edges.

Option D) Kawasaki disease

  • Kawasaki disease typically presents with prolonged fever, erythematous rash, conjunctivitis, and mucosal changes (e.g., strawberry tongue) rather than purpura and joint swelling. It usually does not cause abdominal pain or blood in stools.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the clinic with painless nodular skin lesions on her cheeks and nose for the past three months which occasionally become tender and itchy on exposure to sunlight. She had intermittent episodes of dry cough, shortness of breath, and exercise intolerance. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lupus pernio
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of reddish-purple nodules along with systemic illness suggests the diagnosis of Lupus pernio which is a chronic specific cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis, a multisystem granulomatous disorder.

Lupus Pernio:

  • It is characterized by the presence of violaceous infiltrative plaques with telangiectasia on the convexities of the face.
  • It is often associated with disorders of the upper respiratory tract and can also be associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting terminal phalanges.
  • Diagnosis can be made by classical clinical findings and histopathology showing non-caseating epithelioid cell granuloma.
  • Treatment involves topical and systemic steroids, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

Acne vulgaris (Option A)

  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit.
  • The clinical lesions include non‐inflammatory open and closed comedones with or without papules, pustules, and nodules of varying degrees of inflammation and depth.
  • Treated with retinoids and antibiotics.

 

Rosacea (Option C)

  • Rosacea is a common chronic inflammatory condition marked by recurrent episodes of flushing, erythema, telangiectasia, papules, or pustules.
  • It primarily affects the nose, chin, cheeks, and forehead but spares the perioral area.
  • It is usually triggered by certain factors like environmental temperature and other dietary factors.

 

Lupus vulgaris (Option D)

  • It represents a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary variant of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • The characteristic lesion manifests as a plaque, comprising soft, reddish-brown papules, exhibiting a diascopic appearance resembling apple jelly.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with sudden, painful, red nodules and plaques on her neck and upper arms as shown in the image. Additionally, pseudovesicular lesions are observed. She reports experiencing fever, sore throat, nasal congestion, and malaise for the past week. Skin biopsy reveals dense neutrophilic infiltrates without evidence of vasculitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Sweet syndrome
Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of nodules and plaques on the neck and upper arm, with neutrophilic infiltrates on biopsy, supports the diagnosis of Sweet syndrome which is also called Acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis.

  • It is more common in females.
  • It is associated with:
    • Infections: Streptococcal, URTI, GI infections (Salmonella, Yersinia)
    • Pregnancy
    • IBD, Sjögren’s syndrome
    • Haematological malignancies (AML)
    • Drugs (contraceptives, propylthiouracil)
  • It presents with fever and the sudden appearance of tender, red papules on the face, chest, and trunk; because of prominent dermal oedema, the lesions may appear pseudovesicular, but no fluid is present.
  • Biopsy shows neutrophilic infiltrate without vasculitis is seen.
  • Treated with steroids and potassium iodide.

Option A) Behcet’s disease

  • It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder of unknown aetiology, characterized by systemic vasculitis and neutrophilic dermatosis.
  • The characteristic clinical triad includes manifestations like relapsing uveitis, recurrent genital ulcers, and recurrent oral ulcers (Aphthous ulcers).
  • Aphthous ulcers appear as small erythematous erosions and necrotic centres that heal within a week; oral ones may scar, and genital ones usually don't.
  • Systemic features include non-erosive oligoarthritis (commonly affecting the knee), ocular involvement (posterior uveitis), and potential multisystem manifestations such as pulmonary, cardiac, gastrointestinal, and neurological involvement.
  • Diagnostic feature: Positive pathergy test.
  • Histopathology shows vasculitis and thrombosis.
  • Biopsy shows systemic vasculitis along with neutrophilic dermatosis involving all types and sizes of blood vessels are present.
  • Treated with topical anaesthetics, steroids, or colchicine.

Behcet’s disease is less likely in this case due to the absence of characteristic recurrent oral and genital ulcers, lack of vasculitis on biopsy and the presence of pseudovesicular lesions, which are not typical of Behcet’s disease.

 

Option B) Erythema nodosum

  • Erythema nodosum (EN) is a common acute nodular septal panniculitis characterized by the sudden onset of erythematous, firm, solid, deep nodules or plaques that are tender and typically located on the shins; they heal without scarring.
  • Most common triggers: Bacterial infections, Inflammatory bowel disease, URTI by group Aβ-hemolytic streptococcus, and Tuberculosis
  • It is also associated with Lofgren’s syndrome, an acute form of sarcoidosis.

Option D) Pyoderma gangrenosum

  • It is also a neutrophilic dermatosis but not a bacterial infection (misnomer) and is associated with diseases like Rheumatoid arthritis and IBD.
  • The patient presents with painful papules or lesions on the lower limbs that break down to form ulcers that have a violaceous undermined margin.
  • Pathergy test is positive and heals with atrophic cribriform scarring.

questions.text: Pathergy test is positive in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Psoriasis
Explanation:
Psoriasis shows Koebner’s phenomenon, not positive pathergy.

Koebner phenomenon (Isomorphic phenomenon)

Pathergy

It refers to the development of new lesions of the original disease at sites of skin injury or trauma (scratches, cuts, burns, or even friction)

Pathergy-induced lesions typically manifest as non-specific papules or pustules or enlargement of pre-existing wounds, occurring at sites of minor trauma.

Koebner’s phenomenon is positive in

  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus
  • Vitiligo

Pathergy test is positive in

  • Bechet's disease
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Crohn's disease
    • Genital herpes infection

 

Pathergy test:

  • A positive pathergy test indicates hyperreactivity, which is manifested as an erythematous papule or pustule (>2 mm) within 48 hours of a skin needle prick or intracutaneous injection of 0.1 mL isotonic salt solution.
  • The prick is typically made at a 45-degree angle, 3–5 mm, intracutaneously on the volar forearm.
  • Erythema without infiltration is considered negative.
  • Histopathologically, a monocytic infiltrate is often observed at the positive site.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with painful, raised lesions on her lower legs. Upon examination, tender, erythematous nodules ranging from 1 to 5 cm in diameter as shown in the image are noted bilaterally on the anterior aspects of her shins and are warm to the touch. She had a history of recent upper respiratory symptoms and fatigue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Erythema nodosum
Explanation:

Based on the clinical features and the provided image, the most likely diagnosis is Erythema nodosum.

  • Erythema nodosum is a type of septal panniculitis characterized by the abrupt onset of bilaterally symmetrical, erythematous, firm, subcutaneous nodules or plaques that are tender and predominantly localized on the extensor surfaces of the lower extremities.
  • It is symptomatic, acute in onset, and self-limiting but it can recur.
  • The most common triggers are:
    • Bacterial infections (Streptococcus)
    • Sarcoidosis, TB, IBD
    • URTI by group A β-hemolytic streptococcus (common in children and young adults)
  • Biopsy (confirmatory) shows septal panniculitis without vasculitis and Miescher's radial granulomas.
  • Treatment includes leg elevation, NSAIDS, and colchicine; Steroids are not given.

Option A) Erythema marginatum

  • It presents as an annular rash that typically appears on the trunk, inner aspects of the upper arms, and thighs but seldom on the face.
  • It is non-painful and non-pruritic and commonly occurs in children.
  • The rash is transient, blanches under pressure, and exhibits migratory patterns across the body, lasting from hours to several days.
  • Associated with Rheumatic fever (1–18% of cases).

 

Option B) Erythema multiforme

  • It is a self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis stemming from cell-mediated hypersensitivity, most frequently induced by medications (NSAIDs, sulfonamides, antiepileptics) or infections like HSV (most common) and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • Clinically, it presents with a variety of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, along with the characteristic acral iris or "target lesions."
  • These lesions may involve the palms, trunk, and mucous membranes of the oral and genital regions, often associated with erosions.

 

The image shows the ‘target lesion’ (3 zones: Central dusky erythema, surrounded by a pale edematous ring which is in turn surrounded by an erythematous halo).

Option D) Erythema migrans

  • It represents an initial cutaneous manifestation of Lyme disease, typically appearing at the site of a tick bite.
  • A central spot surrounded by clear skin that is in turn ringed by an expanding red rash is the most typical appearance.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of redness in the eyes, along with joint pain and stiffness. Further history revealed that he had vomiting and diarrhea one week back. On examination, erosions are seen on the glans penis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Reiter’s disease
Explanation:

The triad of polyarthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, suggests that the patient has Reiter’s disease which is also known as Reactive arthritis.

  • It is usually preceded by a gastrointestinal or lower genital tract infection.
  • The triggers include:
    • GI infection: Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter
    • Chlamydia trachomatis
    • HIV
  • HLA association: HLA-B27, HLA-B51
  • Reactive arthritis has 2 skin manifestations:

Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum

Circinate Balanitis

Small vesicles on the hand/palms, covered by hyperkeratotic heaped-up crusts.

Moist, well-defined erosions with a slightly raised micro pustular circinate border on the glans penis.

It is not as painful as herpes.


Renal involvement is usually asymptomatic but sometimes presents with proteinuria, microscopic haematuria, and aseptic pyuria.

Treated with topical steroids (first line), methotrexate, and acitretin (in HIV patients).

Option A) Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammatory arthritis and extra-articular involvement, like rheumatoid nodules.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, non-tender subcutaneous nodules that typically develop over pressure points or areas of repeated trauma, such as the elbows, fingers, heels, and occiput.

Option B) Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • SLE is a systemic condition marked by inflammation of multiple organs, typically affecting the skin, joints, and blood vessels, accompanied by immune system irregularities.
  • Malar rash, or butterfly rash, is a characteristic rash that appears over the cheeks and bridge of the nose and is often associated with photosensitivity.
  • Nonscarring alopecia may occur in individuals with SLE.

Option D) Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a persistent inflammatory condition primarily affecting the axial spine.
  • The predominant symptoms include chronic back pain and gradual restriction of spinal mobility.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the OPD with nodular skin lesions on dorsum of hand. She also gives a history of morning stiffness lasting for about an hour. Examination reveals multiple non-tender firm subcutaneous swellings over several metacarpals (as shown in the image), the left wrist, and both knees. Which of the following statements regarding the patient’s condition is incorrect?

choices.text: More common in patients positive for HLA-DR4

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B
Explanation:

The image shown above of rheumatoid nodules, along with the clinical history of morning stiffness, suggests that the patient is suffering from Rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate causes accelerated rheumatoid nodulosis, not Rituximab.

  • Rheumatoid nodules are palpable subcutaneous nodules, often multiple, and are present in over 20% of individuals with Rheumatoid arthritis, particularly in males, those with seropositive disease, and patients with HLA-DR4 positivity. (Option A is true)
  • Typically asymptomatic, they are commonly found on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees, as well as areas prone to repetitive trauma like sacrum, buttocks, or heels. (Options C and D are true)
  • These nodules are firm in consistency and may ulcerate with trauma, particularly on the sacrum, potentially eroding underlying bone.
  • In some cases, nodules may precede the onset of RA by several years.
  • Histologically, they exhibit characteristic palisading granuloma surrounding a central region of fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Diagnosis is by measurement of anti‐citrullinated peptide antibodies (more specific) and rheumatoid factor.
  • Treatment often involves Rituximab, but drugs like Methotrexate can exacerbate the condition, leading to accelerated rheumatoid nodulosis characterized by rapidly progressive painful nodules on previously unaffected sites.
